7 years as an entrepreneur and 1 takeaway:

Ship more

Nutella was an accident.

During World War II, there wasn't enough cacao, so Pietro Ferrero tried making chocolate with hazelnuts instead. He ended up creating the world's biggest chocolate spread.

Here's why you won’t find good startup ideas:

I share everything I learn as a solopreneur every Saturday morning:

How to find startup ideas, launch fast, and get profitable ↓
Their startup office — My startup office

Put your work out there.

You don’t need an idea to start. Write an article about what you learned last year, rebuild your note-taking app, or send a cold email to a business.

The process of creating will help you discover problems.

Real problems that people would pay you to solve. In the end, you might create a successful business you never even imagined.

Less thinking, more doing.

3. Landing page is as important as the product

On average, only 1 website visitors out of 100 will see your product.

I spent 11 hours on the landing page (37% of the time) to make sure it converts. Here are the key elements I focused on:

For each platform, I try to format the post for the user’s language.

For instance, I use cold tech words on Hacker News, and friendly vibes with emoji on Product Hunt.

I also made a launch skit to kickstart the post on Twitter.

After getting 10,000 I look at just one metric: $ Per Visitor.

- The worst I’ve had is $0.06 per visitor.
- The best is $0.93 (

Getting the 1st customer

To get the first visitors (and customers), I launch everywhere:

Product Hunt, Reddit, Hacker News, and Twitter have the most impact.

I built ZenVoice live on YouTube in 30 hours.

The SaaS made almost $2,000 in 5 days.

The journey from idea to launch ↓

There’s no password reset form, invoice preview, or account deletion. 

But there’s a feedback button so I know what users need instead of making a blind guess.

2. That ONE feature

I had tons of features in mind. But I also remembered that 90% of startups failed. So I have a rule to avoid wasting time (and eventually burning out):

1 startup = 1 feature

For ZenVoice, customers of my users should be able to generate invoices. That’s it.

I only pay for bandwidth (<$1/month) and emails ($0.001 per email).

If a customer generates 49,000+ invoices, I’m losing money. But this will never happen for all customers.

There are 2 plans because people have no clue how much a tool like this costs. Confused customers don't buy. 

The first plan is the anchor, so the second one makes sense.

I went with one-time payments:

- $49: Unlimited invoices for 1 Stripe account
- $69: Unlimited invoices for unlimited Stripe accounts

Building the MVP

1. Pricing is everything

As a customer, that’s what you look at first, especially when you don’t understand the product. As an entrepreneur, that’s how I pay the rent. So I brainstorm pricing first.

A pain with a money incentive is promising.

I didn't find alternatives. So a new startup idea was born:

4/ Unfair advantage

You get attention when you make $55,000/month as a solo founder.

Newsletters, retweets from bigger accounts, YouTubers. People spread the word. It brings traffic to my site, which increases revenue and makes more people spread the word.

Your best bet to become profitable is to show up daily and produce something: a tweet, an app, a video.

You’ll be surprised by what can happen in a few months.

How I built a SaaS startup in 30 hours:

The tech stack I used to build 20+ products:

- Stripe
- NextJS
- Mailgun
- MongoDB
- Tailwind CSS
- No typescript

I've never changed it in the last 2 years.

NextJS is hosted on Vercel and used for the front-end + API.

MongoDB is the database, hosted on MongoDB Atlas.

I use DaisyUI on top of Tailwind CSS for the UI.

And for edge cases, like a CDN, I use AWS.

Here’s what I learned about launching startups Product Hunt ↓

When should you launch?

Monday to Friday are busier. More traffic, but more competition.

- If you’re chasing for the badge, launch on Sunday.
- If you want traffic, launch on Monday (VC startups don’t work on Monday 0:01 AM)

Is it time to launch?

Get social proof first. Ask a few customers/users and add their testimonials to your landing page.

Then, launch as soon as possible, especially if you’re getting started,

The first PH launch is unlikely to be a big hit. And that’s OK. It’s a learning process.

You can re-launch a few months later with new features. Or launch free tools promoting your product (

- Add a badge to your landing page which links to your PH launch page.

Share your launch on other sites like:

- Indie Hackers
- Reddit —

Retweet the launch tweet a few hours later.

I also schedule 2 or 3 tweets later in the day — not related to the launch — so that hopefully one goes viral and newcomers discover my profile (don’t forget to pin your launch tweet).

- Twitter is how you get the most upvotes. Announce your launch with a tweet including the PH link. The tweet needs to stand out.

Each of my launch videos got 300+ likes and my startup got a PH badge — even when I had 1,000 followers. I made

2/ Outbound upvotes

You’ll compete against VC startups, so you need help from outside Product Hunt — outbound upvotes.

Finally, if you learned anything valuable when building your startup, create a Product Hunt conversation on the day of the launch. Plug your launch link at the end. People are already browsing the site, it’s an easy upvote.

When your listing is scheduled, write the first comment.

You’re a solopreneur, not a VC startup — this is inspiring, so write about it.

The comment section supports markdown. Add a link to your product name to maximize traffic.

And plug your Twitter to build an audience.

- Animate your logo as a GIF, it’s such an easy way to get attention because few are doing it

- Images in the gallery should be extremely concise, like a YouTube thumbnail. One feature per image. Zoom on the feature until you can’t before taking the screenshot.

- Your tagline should be short, straight to the point, and possibly trigger an emotional reaction. You can use trendy tech words like GPT-4 but don’t go too deep. Designers, product managers, and marketers must understand your tagline.

1/ Inbound upvotes

There are 2 ways to get upvotes.

Inbound upvotes are given by Product Hunt users who casually browse the site. Your listing should be on point:

- Your startup name should be crystal clear. I wrote about making names people remember:

Building a SaaS Startup — Day 5
Or if you're a Twitch-type:

I never enjoyed marketing.

But I’d never earn $56,000/month without doing some kind of marketing.

I found a better alternative by making free tools that fulfill my inner builder.

↓

The more noise you make, the higher the revenue.

Launch everywhere. Hacker News, Reddit, 𝕏, Product Hunt.

With free tools marketing, it’s common to get media coverage and go viral on TikTok thanks to the embedded virality.

Once you’ve launched, move on to the next free tool.

Each launch will make more noise, increase your daily traffic, and grow your startup — while keeping your inner builder satisfied.

To convert traffic to customers, promote your startup in a seamless way

A simple ad placement gets up to 10% CTR.

You can pump these numbers up when the free tool seamlessly embeds into your customer’s journey, so the promotion feels like an extension of your free tool.

To find ideas, take a standalone feature of your main startup and make a free version of it.

Alternatively, think about what customers would need before using your product.

"I can read 19 books a year with a 15-min daily habit? This habit tracker might help me"

- The experience must start on the homepage. Visitors shouldn’t sign up or click links.
- The app can be hosted on your main website, but it’s best to give it a dedicated domain.

Some guidelines for the best results:

- The app must be free, that’s how you create a viral loop.
- One feature is enough. It must be super simple.
- The name should tell exactly what the app does. That’s how people remember and search on Google.

Free tool marketing consists of launching free and viral mini-apps promoting your main startup.

- You rank for new SEO keywords
- It’s sharable so people spread the word on TikTok
- You grow an audience by launching often
- Your inner builder is motivated to work

- As what people want to read about
- Plug your newsletter under some tweets (i.e. a milestone)
- Show how many people read it (social proof)

- Write 5 headlines, send them to friends, remove the messages after 24 hours, ask which one they remember: That's your winner
- Repurpose your content on 𝕏, link back to your newsletter
- Post a link to your issue on other platforms (Hacker News works well for me)

- Avoid links before 1,000 subscribers
- Plug relevant articles of yours in new issues
- Write today, rewrite tomorrow

My newsletter went from 0 → 10K readers in 5 months.

What I learned:

- Ask for a reply in your welcome email (increase engagement = reduce spam)
- Cut the noise, people won't read 3,000 words on Saturday morning
- Have 1 clear goal for each issue and stick to it

7 lessons from building 9 startups in 2023

#1 Don’t marry your idea

Out of the 20+ startups I launched, only 1 made good money and grew.

It’s the same pattern for most solopreneurs who made life-changing money.

When it’s time to focus on your startup, you’ll know.

#3 Subscriptions headache is real

I killed a startup by swapping one-time payments for recurring ones.

Monthly passive income is good for business owners only. Users are much more reluctant to recurring payments.

Start with one-time payments. Add subscriptions if needed.

#7 Food + Sleep + Workout = Psychiatrist

As a solopreneur, you’re wearing 10 hats (developer + copywriter + accountant…). Burnout is around the corner.

- Eat healthy, avoid carbs, quit sugar and alcohol

- Exercise daily, even if it’s an easy 15-minute workout
- Make sleep your #1 priority. Sleep at the same time every day in a dark room at 18°. Don’t drink coffee 10 hours before bed, don’t drink water 3 hours before bed, dim lights 1 hour before bed.

#6 First impressions matter

In our digital world, it’s the headline of your website, the thumbnail of your YouTube video, or the first sentence of your tweet.

That one sentence has more impact on your conversion rate than anything else.

#2 Emotions sell

Few care about a NextJS boilerplate. But many care about a shortcut to ship startups faster and reach financial independence.

Rephrase your copy to trigger an emotional reaction.

A good night of sleep:

- dark room
- < 1,000 ppm C02
- 18° room temperature
- same sleep time every day
- dim lights 1 hour before bed
- no water 3 hours before bed (avoid toilet)
- no coffee after 12 pm
- no substances

3 years ago I hit rock bottom.

- 0 income
- 0 following
- bad coding skills

Out of despair, I sold PDFs to help men stop dribbling. I ran ads on porn websites and made $8 in 2 months.

A few months of nothingness went by.

Life had no taste. I was broke, out of shape, and living at my parents' house at 28 years old.

One day, I cried without knowing why. Anger came out and dug 4 holes in the wall.

So I did a U-turn: Quit entrepreneurship and got a job.

I'm forever grateful

My life in the last 2 years is filled with happiness. It's hard to believe this ever happened to me.

Wherever you might be right now, life gets better when you do something—anything.

Travel, get a new job, try a new sport.

- Reading
- 8 hours of sleep
- No phone before 3 pm
